For anyone wondering why the trace of a 2X2 matrix is the sum of the eigenvalues, and why the determinant of a 2X2 is the product of the eigenvalues, here's an explanation.

If you solve for lambda by applying the quadratic formula on the characteristic equation given at the end of the video, then you end up with 2 values of lambda (one with a positive square root in the numerator, and one with a negative square root in the numerator). Adding these 2 values of lambda gives you the trace of the matrix, and multiplying the values gives you the determinant of the matrix.

I'd recommend doing the algebra out for yourself.

function [V, D, W] = eig2(A)
m = trace(A)/2;
D = m + (m.^2 - det(A))^(1/2).*[-1 1];
V = [ (D-A(2,2))/A(2,1); 1 1];
D = diag(D);

end

A related application to the angular momentum in a general direction, that might be a little more interesting than just rotating the frame of reference is a 2x2 hamiltonian. The fact that one of the eigenvalues is below the mean and the other one is above can be used to explain the formation of covalent bonds between atoms (the diagonal terms of the hamiltonian are "on-site" energies and the off-diagonal terms are the so-called "hopping integrals"). In that case the eigenvector with the lower eigenvalue represents the bonding state and the one with the higher eigenvalue the anti-bonding state. This example is similar to the spin in a general direction in that it can be expressed in terms of Pauli matrices (because the hamiltonian must be hermitian), but differs in that the squares of the coefficients need not add up to one.

There is also a faster way to find the eigenvectors (which works for any dimension of the matrix, but is especially easy in the 2x2 case), but it uses the Cayley-Hamilton theorem.
The theorem states that the characteristic polynomial of a matrix has the matrix itself as its matrix root, i.e. Chi_A(A) = 0 (btw, its proof is relatively simple and very beautiful). Writing this formula explicitly for a 2x2 matrix A with two eigenvalues k1, k2, we get (A-k_1*E)(A-k_2*E) = 0. Denote the matrix in the second bracket as F. (A-k_1*E)F = 0 <=> AF - k_1*F = 0, which means that the columns of the second matrix, F = (A-k_2*E) are all eigenvectors for the first eigenvalue, k_1, and vice versa. So to find an eigenvector for the eigenvalue k_1, one can just subtract k_2 from the first element of the first row of A (or from the second element of the second row).

Sum of Eigenvalues = trace(A)
Product of Eigenvalues = |A|

And for a 2×2 matrix, (x=Eigenvalue)
x² – (sum of Eigenvalues)x + (product of eigenvalues) = 0

=> x² – trace(A).x + |A| = 0

trace(A)/2 = m
|A| = p
By Sridhara-Acharya's formula,
x (Eigenvalue) = [trace(A) ± √(trace(A)² – 4|A|)]/2

=> x = m±√(m²-p²)

Given A = [[a b c] [d e f] [g h i]] and x, y, z are eigenvalues

trace(A) = x+y+z
(ae-bd)+(ei-fh)+(ai-cg) = xy+xz+yz
det(A) = xyz

The second rule seems weird, but all three rules can be written as "sum of determinants of the nxn matrices along the diagonal = sum of products of n eigenvalue s", where n is the rule number (1, 2, or 3). A related trick that I rarely see mentioned is that you can find eigenvectors associated with each eigenvalue of a 2D matrix simply by subtracting the other eigenvalue from the diagonal of the original matrix. The columns of the resulting matrix will either be an eigenvector or 0. This follows from the Caley-Hamilton theorem, which says that if matrix M has eigenvectors e1, e2, then (M - e1I)(M-e2I) = 0. (If both columns are 0, then your original matrix had to be a multiple of I, so all vectors are eigenvectors in that case.)

The idea of "solving it a different way" has 4 main considerations to keep in mind in the area of teaching.
1. Prohibiting it may restrict students from using a way that they are more familiar with.
2. It may make it hard for students to communicate with teachers (as the teachers might not be familiar with all the most recent tricks).. [Consequently, students might not be interested in considering it.]
3. Sometimes using a different method actually changes the substance of what is being done.
4. Students may forget the formula.

For 3, it is clear that calculating the eigenvalues of a 2 by 2 matrix is a toy problem that illustrates all the ideas of calculating the eigenvalues of a 3 by 3 (or larger sized) matrix: calculate characteristic polynomial using the determinant, find the roots, those are the eigenvalues.
Students who just learn a quick trick might not really be learning how to calculate eigenvalues in general. This is especially so for classes that are using linear algebra only as a tool (e.g. an intro to Differential Equations class) that only have students calculate eigenvalues for 2 by 2 matrices to save their sanity and to not waste too much time on testing linear algebra techniques in a course which focuses on different ideas.
That said, quick tricks are nice. They do teach a similar trick in linear algebra courses, though not as concise.

4 is actually relevant. I have taught a class with the formula for the quasiperiod of an underdamped oscillator, which I provided briefly in class. I also derived it for each example when I needed it, however a number of students did not derive the formula on the exam and just tried to remember the formula. A number of which did so incorrectly.
This is related to how we test student's knowledge. Sometimes problems turn into essentially testing muscle memory and not understanding of what the relevant things mean and where they came from.
